byline.original: Reporting for this page was provided by Michael Molyneux, Kimetris N. Baltrip, Flora Lee, Michelle O'Donnell, Campbell Robertson, C. J. Satterwhite and Daniel B. Schneider

docs.abstract: Article on tenth anniversary of The City section offers statistical snapshot of New York City in 2003 compared with 1993; drawings (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: There's more parkland, and there are more buildings named Trump. There are fewer X-rated emporiums in Times Square, fewer foreign tourists and not a single Checker cab. By measures large and small, New York 2003 wears a far different face than it had when the City section made its debut. LIFE IN THE BIG CITY Checker cabs on New York streets 1993: 10 2003: 0

headline.main: When It Comes to Surgery, He's a Minimalist

docs.abstract: Richard Perez-Pena Public Lives column discusses career and life of Dr Butch Rosser, who is chief of minimally invasive surgery at Beth Israel Medical Center (NYC); photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: PHYSICAL size is pretty much an unavoidable topic around Dr. Butch Rosser. At 6-foot-4 with shoulders wide as a table, he carries his 290 pounds better than most men carry 190. He looks like what he once thought he would be, a National Football League lineman. He speaks with a big voice, big gestures and big ideas about the future of medicine.

headline.main: TV and movie characters sell children snacks.

docs.abstract: Marketing of fruit snacks to children has intensified, with companies making gummy snacks in form of ever more characters licensed from popular toys and hit children's television shows and movies; 45 percent of fruit snacks now have licensing agreements, up from 10 percent in 1996; aiming at children through licensing is hardly new, but scope and intensity of blitz has increased; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: MORGAN NACE, 3, of Madison, Conn., loves the Brach's Wiggles fruit snacks, while his sister, Olivia, 6, prefers the Betty Crocker Disney Princess version. And if buying them each a box means a moment of peace for their mother, Liz, in the supermarket, then it is a no-brainer decision. This is the reality for parents who shop with their children, and it is the driving force for rapidly rising sales of fruit snacks. The marketing of gummy snacks has intensified, making the treats even more appealing to the highly receptive consumers, as companies continue to produce more multiflavored shapes in the form of characters licensed from popular toys and hit children's television shows and movies.
